front.region: FROM DESCRIPTION TO DEPICTION: A CONTINUUM OF VISUAL REPRESENTATION

Jonathan Fish (educator, scientist, artist), 21 College Road, Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, GL53 7HX, U.K. Stephen Scrivener (computer scientist, artist), Department of Computing, University of Technology, Loughborough, Leicestershire, U.K. Received 4 December 1987.

S ketching, or the production of untidy images to assist in the development of visual ideas, is one of the oldest and most familiar activities of artists and designers. It is therefore surprising to find that little has been published about the mental processes that contribute to it. Within the last 20 years, the emergence of the computer, together with its associated technology, as a medium of considerable promise for the manipulation and storage of visual imagery has provided a new urgency to the study of the invisible mental processes that result in the visible activity of sketching. Despite their power and beauty, existing computer- aided sketching systems fail to assistvisual invention as much as they should; yet the increasing capacity of computer systems to record and rapidly manipulate visual images in time and space suggests that they have enormous potential to amplify invention in visual art. In order to design improved systems that are more compatible with the objectives and institutions of artists,it is necessary to analyse and model the functions performed by traditional working methods. These are the premises that led us to write this article. It became apparent to us that no sound decisions could be made, either about the design of new sketching systems or about the appropriate use of existing ones, until a plausible theory of the functions performed by traditional methods could be framed. Descriptive representation is a natural category, but is not easily defined and is loosely associated with a number of other attributes. For example, descriptions are commonly amodal (not specific to a single sense organ). The information in a description is extrinsic, meaning that it only exists by being associated with externally defined rules of interpretation. In contrast, depictive representation (sometimes termed analog representation) is not dependent on externally defined rules of interpretation, be- to that associated with the object, scene or event represented. The colour of a cat may be described by the words 'pale ginger' or depicted by a paint sample that evokes a colour sensation similar to that of the cat. Depictions represent spatial structure in a two- or three- dimensional spatial medium in which there are correspondences between the spatial position in the medium and the spatial position in the thing represented. Much of the information in a depiction is intrinsic,meaning that it is not represented explicitly but can be extracted without rules of interpretation by inspection (e.g. relative size and direction). Depictions are commonly modal (associated with specific modes of perception). Apart from being necessary to represent detailed, concrete spatial information (e.g. the shape of a cat), depictions have the important advantage that they facilitate the search for novel visual relationships not easy to represent descriptively or not easy to find because they are not explicit. Although the distinction between description and depiction is commonly represented as a dichotomy [2, 3, 4], it is better conceived as a continuum in which most visual representations are intermediate between the two theoretical ideals of pure description and pure depiction. Between the extremes of pure mathematical theory and life-size working models lie abstract and concrete words, diagrams, maps, drawings, pictures, photographs, sculptures, film and so on (Table 1). In order to understand sketching, it is necessary to study not only the familiar visible words and pictures used by our culture but also the representational structures used by the brain to classify, store and manipulate visual experience. We posit that sketches have the important function of assisting the mind to translate descriptive propositional information into depiction. This depictive information may then be scanned by atten- tional processes to extract new and per- haps original descriptive information, which in turn can lead to new depiction. The descriptive-to-depictive translation process is a one-to-many map- ping intrinsic to inventive thought. If it is possible to understand how pencil marks on paper can amplify such mental processes, then it should be possible to design greatly improved computer systems. Although the nature of cognitive representation is still an active subject of controversy and debate [5, 6, 7, 8, 9], there is converging evidence that this fuzzy descriptive/depictive distinction characteristic of external human sign systems has analogies in the internal representations used by the brain for perceiving, recognising, imagining and Since the time of Leonardo da Vinci (1452-1519), the familiar attributes of sketches-hurried or untidy lines of pen or crayon on small pieces of paper, tenuous washes of watercolour, rough cross hatching-have remained little changed. It is helpful to reexamine these attributes, however, according to the clues they provide to underlying mental processes. 1. Sketches use abbreviated two- dimensional sign systems to represent three-dimensional visual experience. They do this in two ways. First, lines used in drawing have a variety of descriptive meanings that are (partly, at least) culturally acquired [10, 11, 12]. These sign systems are frequently sup- plemented with written notes. Second, sketches are depictive in the sense that they provoke visual experience resem- bling that associated with the objects or scene represented. Aspects of such pictorial denotation systems have been widely discussed elsewhere [13, 14, 15, 16]. Sketch denotational systems have as their source a stage of information pro- ternscontain the results of these mental analyses and recognition processes. Sketches emphasise those struicttures and features most useful to the latei stages of vision. It is possible that such high-level denotation systems facilitate access to attentive levels of visual imagery. For example, it has been shown that, despite the much smaller amount of information they contain, simple line drawings of objects are recognised at least as quickly as detailed colour photographs of the same objects [29]. The important point is that what we are conscious of when we perceive sketches or real objects is not a static array of luminances and colours but a briefly stored, highly processed mental representation that is continually up- dated by the integration of meaningful fragments from a flow of directed glances.

The distinction referred to earlier between sketching directly by observation from a model and sketching from memory or imagination is that in the first mode the selected information can be continually refreshed by overt attention to vivid perceptual 'snapshots', whilst in the second the source material must be generated and manipulated as much less distinct mental images refreshed by covert attention that appears to mimic real perception. The more vivid percepts, however, cannot be manipulated and recombined like mental images, and they must be integrated by the use of short-term memory. Moreover, it has been widely argued that when we perceive a natural scene our percepts are modified and completed by unconscious expectations (memory) [30, 31]. Therefore, when artists sketch, rather than draw, modification of the percept by mental manipulation is always involved. In other words, the visible marks made will generate mental images that in turn may influence the sketch. This follows from the way we have defined sketching as the making of images used to assist in the design of something else. Purely objective drawing, with no mental manipulation, would not count as sketching. Thus in both modes of sketching, perception and mental imagery in partnership are the key cognitive processes.

front.region: THE STRUCTURE AND FORMAT OF MENTAL IMAGES

Unlike the stable, vivid images of perception, mental images are obtained, not from objects physically stimulating the eyes, but by mentally manipulating remembered representations of features, objects, scenes and events. Ex- cept when one is hallucinating or dreaming, such internally derived images are vaguer and less stable than percepts. In the last 10 years a debate in cognitive psychology has centred around how visual images are represented by the mind [32]. Despite controversy, there is now growing and convergent evidence for at least two types of image representation. The evidence on one type, recognition [33, 34], suggests that the mind has access to categorical representations of visual experience as symbolic structural descriptions. Such representations, sometimes termed 'propositional' because they can be written as a collection of formal propositions, are necessary to explain the fact that object recognition is invariant for size, position, contrast and angle of view. Some such representation must also be postulated to explain the ability to generalise or to recognise the category to which a novel percept belongs. A plausible proposal is that the mind stores visual structures as a top-down hierarchy passing from general shape to the relationships between parts down to the detailed features of individual parts [35, 36]. Such a description is consistent with evidence that suggests that in some circumstances we recognise overall shape before constituent parts [37]. It has also been widely inferred that such hierar- chical descriptions of objects must be linked in turn to 'schemata', larger stored hierarchies or networks of the contextual and semantic information, which have been shown to play an important role in pictorial recognition

The other type of representation, the analog or spatially depictive type, is more controversial [40], but it is be- coming increasingly plausible thanks to the work of Roger Shepard [41 ], Steven Pinker, Ronald Finke, Martha Farah and especially Stephen Kosslyn [42, 43], and their co-workers. Kosslyn proposes that the mental images that resemble percepts are 'quasi-pictorial' spatially depictive maps in which the size, shape and relative distance of a visual element

front.region: are implicit in its position in a matrix of neural elements. Conscious percepts and mental images may share this depictive viewer-centred but three-dimensional format. According to Kosslyn, mental images are generated from propositional descriptions in long-term memory into a grainy, spatial medium, the 'visual buffer', where objects and their features can be independently recombined, moved, rotated and re- scaled at high speed. Moreover, mental images can be scanned and 'inspected' internally, and parts can be magnified, revealing more detail, as in a computer- graphics zoom function. The evidence for this theoretical model for imagery is based not just on introspective reports but also on a wealth of subtle detection, discrimination and reaction- time experiments. For example, in an early experiment subjects were shown shapes (Fig. 3) [44]. It was found that the time taken to determine whether the two shapes were identical was linearly related to the angle through which one of the shapes would have to be rotated to bring it into congruence with the other. This is consistent with subjects' introspective reports of mental image rotation. In another experiment, Kosslyn [45] asked his subjects to memorise a map of an island on which seven objects were located in such away that the distances between any pair of objects was different. He then asked them to form a mental image of the map, focusing on one named object, and to then scan to another one and report whether the named object pos- sessed a certain feature. He found that the time taken to scan between two parts of the mental image was directly related to the distance between them in the actual map. This finding has been extended to three dimensions by Pinker and Finke [46], suggesting that the medium of mental imagery must be three-dimensional. It has also been shown [47] that it takes longer to form a detailed image than to form a simple outline and that images can be constructed mentally from separately memorised parts. Moreover, there is evidence that mental images are generated from stored parts that are structured in agreement with the way they are structured in perception [48]. Thus there is objective evidence that spatially depictive images generated from memory have many of the properties needed to explain the ability of artists and designers to generate, manipulate, combine and inspect in imagination nonexistent visual objects. Mental images may resemble percepts because they have evolved to assist us to anticipate real percepts [49] and to solve problems by visual simulation of possible events. It is likely that mental images also have the natural function of completing, from memory, incomplete percepts from brief, low-con- trastor otherwise impoverished stimuli. The question that has not been an- swered (and has been little discussed [50]) is, How do the depictive marks, suggestive scribbles and indeterminacies of the sketch amplify and assist the manipulation of mental images and (as Leonardo's theory suggests) provoke the generation of new ones? There is ample evidence that percepts and mental images compete for the same modality-processing capacity in the brain (e.g. visual, auditory, tactile, verbal). For example, Brooks [51] found that a visual pointing response interfered more with a visual imagery task than with a verbal response and, conversely, that a spoken response interfered more with an auditory imagery task than with a visual response. Simi- larly, Segal and Fusella [52] found that subjects instructed to form visual images made more errors in detecting a small but unrelated visual target than if instructed to form auditory images, and vice versa. There is also evidence that visual percepts and images have a similar structure and format. For example, the size and shape of the field that can be inspected mentally is the same as the field of view in normal fixated vision. Moreover, like the visual field, the corresponding image field has high resolution at the centre and declines in resolution to the same extent in both the horizontal and the vertical dimensions. It has also been shown that in certain circumstances visual images and low-contrast percepts may be confused. Perky [53] asked subjects to form mental images of familiar objects against a two-waymirror. Unknown to them, she then gradually projected from behind a faint actual image of the same object. None of her subjects noticed that a real image was present, and all attributed characteristics of the real image to their mental images. Segal and Nathan [54], using more controls, confirmed this finding. They also provided evidence for assimilation of the percept into the image. For example, when subjects were asked to form a mental image of a city skyline but were shown a tomato (subjects were inside a hood with a concealed projector), sev- eral described the skyline with a round sun behind it setting in a red sky. Segal [55] interprets these and other results as evidence that percepts can be fused with images and even that the image may be constructed around an unde- tected physical signal. It has also been demonstrated that images can facilitate percepts. Farah [56] asked subjects to memorise and then mentally image either an uppercase Hor an uppercase 7T. Whilst doing this with eyes fixed, they were given a forced-choice detection task of similar H's or 7T'sin random order. Farah found that the detection rate for either letter was facilitated if the same letter had been imaged and that this facilita- tion was dependent on the image and the stimulus letters being in the same position in the visual field. Farah interprets this result as proving that images and percepts share the same representational medium. Support for the shared representation hypothesis comes from the study of unilateral visual neglect, a type of visual problem that results from stroke damage to a part of the parietal cortex known to be associated with visual attention and spatial perception. The left half of the visual field is known to be mapped in the right hemisphere of the brain, and vice versa. If the damage is in the right side of the brain only, the patient has difficulty attending to objects in the left half of the visual field, even though it can be shown that isolated objects can still be seen in the left visual field. Bisiach and Luzzatti [57] showed in two patients that unilateral visual neglect was also accompanied by a matching neglect for the left half of a memory image. Thus if images and percepts share the same visual processes and have a shared neural medium, and if images facilitate percepts, it seems plausible that percepts arising from sketches can facilitate and amplify mental imagery. Since the history of sketching is too recent to make it likely that it has af- fected the evolution of the human visual system, it is also probable that the sketch exploits imagery processes that evolved for a different ecological function. Part of this may have been the completion from memory of fragmentary percepts. Because objects in the natural environment are so frequently partlyobscured by other objects or seen incompletely in momentary glances, the visual system has evolved a recognition system that is able to reconstruct images of whole objects from perceived parts and fragments. Hoffman and Richards [58] have proposed a system of segmentation of object contours at regions of concavity for part recognition that helps to explain the effective- ness of incomplete contours (see Fig. 1) and pentimenti in sketches. Biederman [59] has suggested a related recognition scheme based on a lexicon of 36 canonical volumes. Like the ink blots in the Rorschach test, other types of sketch indeterminacy may trigger innate recognition search mechanisms into generating a stream of imagery useful to invention. PERCEPT-IMAGE HYBRIDS For solving complex visual problems, mental images have an advantage over percepts, even computer-generated ones, in the speed and flexibility with which they can be manipulated. Their disadvantage lies in their haziness and brevity. There is convergent evidence that the visual medium in working memory available to attention has a low spatial capacity and short duration [60]. According to Kosslyn's 1980 model of mental imagery, images fade quickly and must be continually re- generated from long-term memory. This disadvantage may be lessened, however, when they are superimposed over a real perceived scene to anticipate the visual results of some physical manipulation. A familiar example is that of looking at one's room and visually imagining the rearrangement of the furniture. Whilst it is clearly a help to be able to look at the room while doing this, it is also a common experience that part of the room percept, such as other furniture, may hinder rather than assist the formation of the required image. As already mentioned, it has been shown that images can be generated from separately encoded parts, and chronometric studies suggest that an outline skeletal structure is imaged before the addition of parts and detail [61]. It is reasonable to assume that many sketches-e.g. Picasso's studies for Les demoiselles d'Avignon [62]-are skeletal structures that substitute a percept for the stable part of an image-per- cept hybrid and by reducing the amount of image regeneration necessary enable the imagery-transform processes greater speed and scope. It is therefore necessary for an imagery theory of sketching to determine how the sketch-denotation percepts are best able to facilitate the rapid manipulation of superimposed imagery without also limiting or hindering it. Surprisingly, little research seems to have been done on the role of such hybrid images in art. Relevant data, however, can be obtained from research into the use of imagery in chess. Here the board and pieces have a function analogous to the sketch percept. In

In addition, ing propositional or descriptive recog- traditional media do not record or use nition mechanisms rather than the spa- the temporal information intrinsic to the flow of visual thought, and they make it difficult to represent and manipulate three-dimensional structure. Computers have great potential to over- come these limitations, provided depictive mental imagery and semantic knowledge underlying sketch surface structure can be represented and passed between mind and machine. Ex- isting computer sketching systems usually represent the image as a list of numbers, or bit-map, representing the colour and brightness of tiny square picture elements called pixels. These are mapped electronically by a raster display system via a colour look-up table onto the red, green and blue phos- phors of a video monitor. The resolution or grain of the image depends on the number of pixels, and the quality of the colour depends on the number of binary digits used to represent each pixel in the bit-map. Raster graphics software allows the user to directly manipulate the bit-map corresponding to this image. Although there are many advantages to such systems over paper and paint, neither perceived structure nor mental imagery is represented, and so neither can be directly manipulated. Objects to be coloured or moved must be precisely drawn to indicate their position and shape. The suggestive indeterminacies of sketches, so useful for mental processing, thus constitute one of the hardest denotation systems to manipulate in the typical raster graphics paint box system. Thus whilst painting systems resemble traditional media, they offer little scope for ampli- fying the art-and-design process. Another type of computer-aided design system stores visual objects as lists of numerical coordinates that are joined, using fast built-in procedures, by straight or curved lines, in order to be mapped onto the bit-map for raster display or to be used to control a me- chanical pen. This way of representing and manipulating images is known as vector graphics, and it allows the struc- turing of an image into contours, parts and objects. Moreover, the shape of an object can be represented in three- dimensional coordinates and then mapped by perspective projection onto the screen or pen plotter as it would be seen from any particular viewpoint. A great deal of computing ingenuity and mathematical skill has been devoted to such 'wire-frame'and 'solid modelling' systems, often with the apparent objective of achieving a detailed photographic realism. Despite their value as visual model- ling tools, such systems have little room for the indeterminacies and other image-supporting structures implicit in the Leonardo method of sketching, and they are rarely used in the early stages of design. The precision and realism of the image generated by such systems may inhibit the formation of the percept-image hybrids so important in the early stages of problem solving. Negroponte [68] has characterised the design of many computer-assisted design (CAD) systems as conforming to a 'partitioned idiot slave' paradigm, in which no attempt is made to pass information about the user's mental processes to the machine nor to inform the user about transparent data structures used by the machine to construct the visible image. Artists who work with commercially available computer software [69] usually accept the limitations and treat the system as a new medium, adapting their style and imagery to the machine's capability. The ability to perform rapid colour fills, cut and paste, rescale, zoom in on detail, and animate and generate perspective views of detailed solid objects provides ample opportunity for experiment and invention. They would probably argue that there is no need to sketch, because direct and detailed manipulation of the medium is an im- provement on the vagueness of early sketches. This is a natural way of working similar to that used by many paint- ers who manipulate paint on canvas directly with little if any preliminary study. Other artists find the available software restrictiveand acquire (usually by self-education) the skills necessary to write their own [70]. Here the individu- ality and original style characteristic of contemporary art becomes as much an attribute of the software as of the images generated. Particularly interesting in this re- spect is the recent work of Harold Cohen, who in 1968, already a suc- cessful abstract artist, studied programming and artificial intelligence with Edward Feingenbaum at Stan- ford University [71]. Cohen's program AARON, which he has been developing for over 15 years in order to research the nature of visual representation, pro- duces endlessly varied drawings on pen plotters from a hierarchically structured set of rules or 'strategies' (Fig. 7). This way of working is not sketching, but AARON's procedures have some of the characteristics of sketching, and Cohen treated a number of AARON's products as if they were sketches, using them to make large hand-coloured murals. But there are probably many artistswho are not prepared to espouse the individual program approach, because they demand a more immediate interaction with a visual medium (Cohen's program is noninteractive). For these artists, existing systems, with their photographic realism, detailed precision and limited scope for serendipity, may have little advantage over traditional sketching media. Despite the inappropriate design of existing software, computer systems offer enormous potential advantages over paper and pencil. We cannot safely specify or design improved systems, nor replace old ways of working, until we understand the subtle mental images that our media extend. Exactly how such new sketching systems should be designed is the subject of current research. CONCLUSION Despite scholarly arguments for a greater emphasis on visual modes of thought [72], Western culture and education are still dominated by verbal/ propositional reasoning and information storage. New evidence of the importance of mental imagery in memory, reasoning and invention, and research that reveals the awesome proportion of the brain that is dedicated to vision, emphasise the need to redress the im- balance. The evidence from cognitive science suggests that the mind uses imagery and verbal processes for comple- mentary and interdependent purposes. This suggests that it may be an error to separate, as we tend to do, visual or depictive from propositional modes of education. Information technology has a growing capacity to store and manipulate pictorial information much more dynamically than has hitherto been possible. In order to harness this capacity, the designers of improved computer systems for artistsmust attempt to understand the internal as well as the external representations and processes used by artists for visual invention. We hope that this approach will lead to computer software that is more compatible with visual cognition. It would be helpful if such expanded computer systems could also contribute to the solution of the problem of translation between differing modes of thought, which remains a ghostly barrier to pro- gress in education and culture.
